description: From Middle English amenden, from Old French amender, from Latin ēmendō (“free from faults”), from ex (“from, out of”) + mendum (“fault”). Compare aphetic mend.

entries.meaning: (usually in the plural) An act of righting a wrong; compensation.
(informal, of a document, usually in the plural) Clipping of amendment (“alteration or change for the better”).
examples: I've sent over a new version of the doc with some amends.

verbs.description: amend (third-person singular simple present amends, present participle amending, simple past and past participle amended)

examples: The teacher sat at one end of the bench, with a meek little fellow by his side. When the others were disorderly, this young martyr received a rap; intended, probably, as a sample of what the rest might expect, if they didn't amend.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To heal (someone sick); to cure (a disease etc.).
(obsolete, intransitive) To be healed, to be cured, to recover (from an illness).
(transitive) To make a formal alteration (in legislation, a report, etc.) by adding, deleting, or rephrasing.
examples: The following motions cannot be amended:
